title: sec1: blanket impl ModulusSize for all typenums
body:
Instead of `impl_modulus_size!` for a number of types, impl `ModulusSize` for all types. This is useful for testing, see https://github.com/RustCrypto/formats/pull/1649

Note: the bound `UntaggedPointSize: Add<U1, Output = Self::UncompressedPointSize>` caused issues because there's another bound with `Output = Self::UncompressedPointSize`, and I don't think Rust's type system allows one to assert that two associated types are equal.

Removing that bound did not cause compilation issues, but it left the tag size unconstrained. So instead I added the `Add<U1, Output = Self::CompressedPointSize>` bound on `ModulusSize` itself.

title: x509-cert: support for GN in names
body:
This brings support for parsing `GN` as `givenName` in the `x509_cert::name::Name`

Fixes #1647

body:
Bumps [getrandom](https://github.com/rust-random/getrandom) from 0.2.15 to 0.3.0.
Changelog

Sourced from getrandom's changelog.

[0.3.0] - 2025-01-25

Breaking Changes

Changed

  • Bump MSRV to 1.63 #542
  • Rename getrandom and getrandom_uninit functions to fill and fill_uninit respectively #532

Removed

  • wasm32-wasi target support (use wasm32-wasip1 or wasm32-wasip2 instead) #499
  • linux_disable_fallback, rdrand, js, test-in-browser, and custom crate features in favor of configuration flags #504
  • register_custom_getrandom! macro #504
  • Implementation of From<NonZeroU32> for Error and Error::code method #507
  • Internet Explorer 11 support #554
  • Target-specific assocciated Error constants #562

Changed

  • Use ProcessPrng on Windows 10 and up, and use RtlGenRandom on older Windows versions #415
  • Do not use locale-specific strerror_r for retrieving error code descriptions #440
  • Avoid assuming usize is the native word size in the rdrand backend #442
  • Do not read from errno when libc did not indicate error on Solaris #448
  • Switch from libpthread's mutex to futex on Linux and to nanosleep-based wait loop on other targets in the use_file backend #490
  • Do not retry on EAGAIN while polling /dev/random on Linux #522
  • Remove separate codepath for Node.js in the wasm_js backend (bumps minimum supported Node.js version to v19) #557
  • Use js_namespace in the wasm_js backend #559

Added

  • wasm32-wasip1 and wasm32-wasip2 support #499
  • getrandom_backend configuration flag for selection of opt-in backends #504
  • Error::new_custom method #507
  • rndr opt-in backend #512
  • Automatic MemorySanitizer support #521 #571
  • u32 and u64 functions for generating random values of the respective type #544
  • wasm32v1-none support in the wasm_js backend #560
  • wasm_js crate feature which allows users to enable the wasm_js opt-in backend #574

Fixed

  • NetBSD fallback code based on KERN_ARND #555

title: serdect v0.3.0
body:
NOTE: this release includes major breaking changes to the wire format, namely all bytestrings now include a length prefix, even when serializing fixed-size arrays. This is intended to work around deficiencies in the `serde` API (see serde-rs/serde#2120) as well as serde-based format implementations which have variable-time behavior when using `serialize_tuple`.

Any binary data serialized with previous versions of `serdect` now needs a length prefix prepended to the data, which will vary depending on the particular data format.

### Changed
- Switch to length-prefixed encoding using the `serialize_bytes` method ([#1112], [#1515])
- MSRV 1.70 ([#1244])

[#1112]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/formats/pull/1112
[#1515]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/formats/pull/1515
[#1244]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/formats/pull/1244

title: chore(deps): bump hashbrown from 0.15.0 to 0.15.2
body:
### [RUSTSEC-2024-0402](https://rustsec.org/advisories/RUSTSEC-2024-0402.html)

> Borsh serialization of HashMap is non-canonical

| Details             |                                                |
| ------------------- | ---------------------------------------------- |
| Package             | `hashbrown`                      |
| Version             | `0.15.0`                   |
| URL                 | [https://github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/576](https://github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/576) |
| Date                | 2024-10-11                         |
| Patched versions    | `>=0.15.1`                  |
| Unaffected versions | `<0.15.0`               |

The borsh serialization of the HashMap did not follow the borsh specification.
It potentially produced non-canonical encodings dependent on insertion order.
It also did not perform canonicty checks on decoding.

This can result in consensus splits and cause equivalent objects to be
considered distinct.

This was patched in 0.15.1.

title: const-oid: replace panics with `checked_*!` macros
body: Returns `Error::Overflow` if any operations overflow

title: const-oid: fix (and simplify) base 128 encoder
body:
This changes the base 128 decoder to calculate the length of a base 128-encoded arc and then iterates over each byte, computing the value for that byte, without any mutable state other than the position.

It also refactors the unit tests and adds an example extracted from proptest failures. The new implementation passes that test.

Closes #1585

title: const-oid: basic `split_hi_bits` smoke tests
body: Adds internal tests which check the basic behavior of `split_hi_bits` in the OID encoder logic.

title: const-oid: elimiate arithmetic side effects in arc encoder
body: Ensures overflow will always cause a panic instead

title: const-oid: eliminate `split_high_bits` side effects
body: Prefer panicking instead so underflow bugs aren't silent

title: const-oid: add basic proptests
body: Exercises the parser beyond what we currently do in unit tests

title: const-oid: handle repeated dot characters in input
body: Adds an `Error::RepeatedDot` case and handles it within the parser

title: const-oid: test max arc edge case; more coverage
body: Changes an example to test the `u32::MAX` edge case for OIDs, and ensures all of the relevant methods are tested.

title: const-oid: improve rustdoc on `Arc`
body:
Note that we follow Mozilla conventions using maximum 32-bit arcs, linking to a survey of various OID libraries and how they handle various sized arcs.

Also notes we deliberatly do not support UUIDs-as-OIDs, since they're not important (at least within the scope of what we currently implement) to cryptographic use cases this library is intended for.

title: const-oid: fix large arc handling
body:
As originally reported in #1585

The maximum size of a serialized arc was miscomputed, since it failed to include the additional bits needed to store the LEB128 encoding.

Also adds checked arithmetic to the calculation of an arc from base 10, both fixing a clippy warning and an overflow bug.

title: tls_codec: implement traits for Box<T>
body: Implement all relevant traits for `Box<T>` as long as T implements the respective trait.

title: Add new action to update leap seconds automatically
body:
Resolves : https://github.com/RustCrypto/formats/issues/675

This PR adds a github actions that runs each week, to check for the leap seconds change in a reputable source and creates a PR to update if necessary.

The PR doesn't contains the process to release automatically as the process could change and maybe we don't want to directly change the version and make the release.

This current PR also include the changes to start with the current value 37 seconds.
Here is some tests I did on a fork : https://github.com/AurelienFT/formats/actions/runs/11470018305/job/31918401654 / https://github.com/AurelienFT/formats/pull/5/files

It could be nice to release a new major this time to have the correct time available for everyone.

title: x509-cert: move CSR builder to x509_cert::request
body: See https://github.com/RustCrypto/formats/issues/1577

title: base64ct: derive additional traits on alphabets
body: This PR will implement all derivable std-traits mentioned in [C-COMMON-TRAITS](https://rust-lang.github.io/api-guidelines/interoperability.html) for base64-alphabets. This allows using these types e.g. as `PhantomData<E> where E: Encoding` and derive `PartialOrd` for the container-type. These alphabet-types are unit-structs, so there is not really a reason not to derive everything possible to make them more usable.

title: CI: disable `security-audit` cache
body:
We're encountering errors like:

      /home/runner/.cargo/bin/cargo-audit: /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6: version `GLIBC_2.39' not found (required by /home/runner/.cargo/bin/cargo-audit)

These are occurring even with freshly-built binaries.

To avoid blocking PRs, temporarily disable the build cache until we have time to properly investigate.

body:

Closes https://github.com/RustCrypto/formats/issues/1543

title: cms: use `dep:` syntax for `builder` feature in Cargo.toml
body: Gets rid of implicit features for each optional dependency

title: cms: remove `alloc` feature
body: The crate has a hard dependency on liballoc, so it shouldn't be feature-gated

title: cms: remove unused transitive `pem` feature activation
pkcs12: make `zeroize` dependency optional
body:
Only the `kdf` feature uses it.

Closes #1558

title: cms: remove `pem` feature
body: Closes #1557

title: der_derive: use `TryFrom` conversions for `asn1(type = ...)`
body:
Previously it was using `<asn1_type>::new`.

Using `TryFrom` is more flexible in terms of the possible conversions that it permits.

Also fills out the missing `From`/`TryFrom` conversions needed for the existing crates in this repo (most notably `x509-cert` to compile with the changes).

title: der: Custom error types in derive macros.
body:
Add support for specifying a custom decode error type for `Sequence`, `Enumerated` and `Choice` derive macros using the `#[asn1(error = Ty)]` attribute.

This addresses #1559.

title: const-oid: add RFC 5753 OIDs
body:
**Overview**
This PR adds `RFC5753` OIDs to `const-oid`, as discussed in https://github.com/RustCrypto/formats/issues/1546.

**Rationale**
[RFC 5753 (Use of Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) Algorithms in Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS))](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5753) describes the use of ECC in CMS.
It would be needed for implementation of ECC in CMS - https://github.com/RustCrypto/formats/issues/1544

Since this was the only usage of `std`, also removes the `std` feature.

title: x509-cert: re-export `spki` types without `*Owned` suffixes
body:
Re-exports the following with shorter names:
- `spki::AlgorithmIdentifierOwned` => `x509_cert::AlgorithmIdentifier`
- `spki::SubjectPublicKeyInfoOwned` => `x509_cert::SubjectPublicKeyInfo`

These names are already quite long to begin with even without the `*Owned` suffix.

The `x509-cert` crate has a hard dependency on `alloc` and always uses the `*Owned` types, so this allows for more convenient names in this scenario.

body: This is a followup on #1531 and #1532

body: ecdsa 0.17.0-pre.9 and p256 0.14.0-pre.2 have now been published

title: x509-cert: adds a `Validity::new` method
body: Having the profile be private makes it impossible to create a `Validity`. This adds a `Validity::new` to do that.

title: x509-cert: creates a validity to infinity
body: This is used for idevid certificates burned in hardware.

title: x509-cert: restore Copy for Validity
body:
x509_cert::time::Validity used to have Copy, but because it now carries a Profile, it may lose the Copy trait

This forces the profile to be copyable. Profile should not carry state so I don't believe this is much of an issue.

title: const-oid: fix large arc handling in encoder
body:
BER encodings were being miscomputed for certain large arcs.

The previous method was a bit wacky (in addition to being buggy) and attempted to encode each arc backwards within the BER output buffer.

This switches to a new method which splits the upper 7 bits from an arc and encodes that as a byte, continuing until all bytes of the arc have been encoded, which is much more straightforward.

The problematic cases which were reported have now been corrected.

Fixes #1520

cc @zhengyao-lin

title: pkcs5: allow empty algId prf parameter for PBES2 params
body:
Rationale: some applications and libraries produce PBES2/PBKDF2 structures without the terminating NULL value specified in the prf algorithm field.
This PR relaxes the decoding requirements.

According to [RFC4231](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4231#section-3.1) the NULL parameter should be present but is not an absolute requirement.

See for example this issue: https://github.com/ancwrd1/p12-keystore/issues/2

title: der: remove remaining `doc(cfg(...))`
body: We now use `doc_auto_cfg` instead

title: x509-cert: use `BuilderProfile` for consistency
body:
followup on #1514.

Use `BuilderProfile` instead of `BuildProfile` for consistency with the builder.
